questions.question: What is the primary purpose of tool use in LLMs?
options: To make the model generate longer responses
To allow the model to interact with external systems and take actions
To reduce the model's training time
To replace the need for prompt engineering
questions.explanation: Tool use bridges the gap between text generation and real-world interaction, letting the model invoke functions, call APIs, and perform actions.

questions.question: When an LLM makes a function call, the model itself executes the function directly.
questions.explanation: The LLM only generates a structured request (function name and arguments). Your application code is responsible for actually executing the function and returning the result.

questions.question: In Semantic Kernel, what attribute is used to expose a C# method as a tool the LLM can call?
questions.explanation: Semantic Kernel uses the [KernelFunction] attribute along with [Description] to register C# methods as callable tools for the model.

questions.question: What is the difference between a 'tool' and a 'skill' in the context of agent development?
options: There is no difference â€” the terms are interchangeable
A tool is a single function, while a skill is a group of related tools covering a domain
A skill is simpler than a tool
Tools are for reading data, skills are for writing data
questions.explanation: A tool is a single function (e.g., SendEmail), while a skill (or plugin) groups related tools into a domain-specific collection that the agent can use together.

questions.question: Which design principle is most important for building skills that compose well?
options: Each function should handle as many responsibilities as possible
Functions should have vague descriptions so the model has flexibility
Each function should do one thing well with a clear description
Functions should always return plain text strings
questions.explanation: Single responsibility and clear descriptions are essential. The model relies on descriptions to select the right tool, and focused functions are easier to chain together reliably.
